required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Study on the Effect of Position on Walking Labour Epidural Efficacy
clinical_study.official_title: Which Position is Best: A Randomized Clinical Trial on the Effect That Position Has on Walking Labour Epidural Analgesia

brief_summary.textblock: This study is being done to better understand how patient positioning can affect pain relief after an epidural. In addition to pain, the investigators will assess how position affects epidural spread, and its effects on maternal blood pressure and fetal heart rate.

detailed_description.textblock: Epidurals will be placed with parturients in the standard sitting position. An epidural catheter will be placed to a depth of 5 cm into the epidural space. After placement, parturients will be randomized to one of the four position groups (left uterine displacement, left lateral, right lateral, or seated upright). After successful positioning, a series of 5 cc bolus doses of 0.08% ropivacaine with 2 mcg per cc of fentanyl will be injected through the epidural catheter in 5 minute intervals for a total volume of 20 cc. After the initial loading dose of epidural solution has been injected in the first 20 minutes post-insertion, the patient will be able to return to whatever position they are most comfortable with. The parturient will be asked to rate their pain on a verbal pain scale of between 0 and 10 at the peak of their contraction at three time intervals. The spread of the blockade will be assessed with ice applied along both the left and right mid-clavicular lines. Maternal blood pressure will be measured on the upper arm in all patients as per nursing protocol. Fetal heart rate will be monitored intermittently with Doppler ultrasound as per nursing protocol.

primary_outcome.measure: Labour pain based on verbal rating pain scale
primary_outcome.time_frame: Taken at time 0 minutes after epidural insertion
primary_outcome.description: Pain with contractions, assessed using a 0 to 10 verbal rating pain scale; 0 being no pain with a contraction and 10 being the worse pain with a contraction.

primary_outcome.measure: Labour pain based on verbal rating pain scale
primary_outcome.time_frame: Taken at time 20 minutes after epidural insertion
primary_outcome.description: Pain with contractions, assessed using a 0 to 10 verbal rating pain scale; 0 being no pain with a contraction and 10 being the worse pain with a contraction.

primary_outcome.measure: Labour pain based on verbal rating pain scale
primary_outcome.time_frame: Taken at time 40 minutes after epidural insertion
primary_outcome.description: Pain with contractions, assessed using a 0 to 10 verbal rating pain scale; 0 being no pain with a contraction and 10 being the worse pain with a contraction.

secondary_outcome.measure: Assessment of epidural levels based on dermatomes
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Taken at time 20 minutes after epidural insertion
secondary_outcome.description: Levels of analgesia assessed via temperature insensitivity to ice on the right and left side along the midclavicular lines of the patient and reported as dermatome levels.

secondary_outcome.measure: Assessment of epidural levels based on dermatomes
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Taken at time 40 minutes after epidural insertion
secondary_outcome.description: Levels of analgesia assessed via temperature insensitivity to ice on the right and left side along the midclavicular lines of the patient and reported as dermatome levels.

secondary_outcome.measure: Category of epidural based on bilateral dermatome levels
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Taken at time 20 minutes after epidural insertion
secondary_outcome.description: Epidural assessed if it is successful, unilateral (more than two dermatome level difference between sides), patchy (one or more areas between dermatomes that remain sensitive to temperature assessment), or failed (no measurable dermatome levels) based on the dermatome levels gathered by nursing assessments.

secondary_outcome.measure: Category of epidural based on bilateral dermatome levels
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Taken at time 40 minutes after epidural insertion
secondary_outcome.description: Epidural assessed if it is successful, unilateral (more than two dermatome level difference between sides), patchy (one or more areas between dermatomes that remain sensitive to temperature assessment), or failed (no measurable dermatome levels) based on the dermatome levels gathered by nursing

secondary_outcome.measure: Events of maternal hypotension after epidural placement
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Blood pressure taken with a non-invasive blood pressure monitoring cuff every 5 minutes for 20 minutes after epidural insertion
secondary_outcome.description: Hypotensive events defined as a deviation of greater than 20% of maternal blood pressure compared to pre-epidural baseline.

secondary_outcome.measure: Events of fetal bradycardia after epidural placement
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Intermittent fetal heart rate monitoring via doppler as per nursing protocol for 20 minutes after epidural insertion
secondary_outcome.description: Fetal bradycardic events defined as a fetal heart rate of less than 120 bpm after epidural placement.

arm_group.description: Supine with left tilt for uterine displacement

intervention.description: Parturients will have an epidural placed in the upright seated position as per institution standard. After epidural placement, they will be positioned as per their randomization. They will then have a total of 20 cc of epidural solution (0.08% ropivacaine with 2 mcg per cc of fentanyl) injected into the epidural in boluses of 5 cc every 5 minutes.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Active labour or admitted for induction of labour
- Requesting an epidural for labour analgesia
- Contractions occurring greater than once every 5 minutes
Exclusion Criteria:
- Coagulation disorder
- High risk pregnancy as per obstetrics
- Spinal pathology (included scoliosis, herniated disks, or previous lumbar back surgery)
